awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Rechargeable Batteries with Ultrafast Charging Capability and Long Usage Time per Charge
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation-Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to develop silicon-based rechargeable batteries that can charge fast and can maintain a charge longer. Such batteries will allow cell phones to be charged to their full capacity in 20 minutes, compared with current standards of 2 hours; and will extend usage time to 3 days, rather than 2, prior to needing recharging.  The ultrafast charging batteries and high energy batteries would impact other important products, ranging from cameras and laptops to drones, power tools, electric forklifts, military devices, and others.  Silicon-based high-energy batteries could reduce the cost and weight of the battery pack by 60% in electric vehicles. The scientific understanding derived from this project would enable translation of silicon-based battery technology into consumer electronics applications in the near term and electric vehicle applications in the longer term.
 
The proposed project employs a novel, simple and low cost manufacturing method that can synthesize a new type of Si-based anode powder that exhibits unusual properties with ultrafast charging capability, high specific capacity and long cycle life simultaneously. The objective of this research is to overcome technical challenges in translating this new half-cell technology into full cell rechargeable batteries with unprecedented ultrafast charging capability, high specific energy and long cycle life. Six research tasks will be performed to address the challenges of low Coulombic efficiency and irreversible Li loss in the first formation cycle of full cells, cathode material design, correct matching of anode and cathode capacities for high specific energy, proper selection of cutoff voltages of full cells to minimize capacity decay during cycles, and design of full cells capable of ultrafast charging without Li plating. Three-electrode pouch cell investigation and post-mortem analysis of full cells with different active material loadings per unit area and charge/discharge rates after different cycles will be conducted to develop fundamental understanding and provide guidance to address the aforementioned challenges and achieve the research objective.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The overarching objective of this project is to conduct applied research to achieve high energy, high power and long cycle life Si anodes for Li-ion batteries. Intellectual Merit: We have developed a patent pending process to synthesize Si/C core/shell particles with internal engineered voids which can partially accommodate the giant volume changes (~300%) during charge and discharge (i.e., lithiation and delithiation), thereby providing a stable interface for the formation of solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. Because of the unique design of the nanoscale Si/C core/shell particles, the specific capacities of Si/C core/shell anodes at the electrode level (i.e., including the weights of carbon black and PAA binder) exhibit 169% and 91% higher than those of the state-of-the-art graphite anodes at the 1st and 500th cycles, respectively. Furthermore, the Si/C core/shell anodes are capable of ultrafast charging, reaching 50% of the total specific energy in 3 min and 80% in 50 min with specific energy at 336 Wh/kg. The patent pending process is scalable and environmentally benign at low cost. As a result of these features, this newly established patent pending process has the potential to be a viable process for commercialization. Broader Impacts:  The Si-based batteries derived from the nanoscale Si/C core/shell particles have enormous societal impacts because they have the potential to replace the current graphite anodes for next-generation Li-ion batteries with higher energy and higher power at lower costs in the near future. This project has provided research training and education to two PhD students and two undergraduate students in the areas of materials synthesis, powder processing, microstructural characterization, electrochemical evaluation, battery manufacturing and testing. Furthermore, this project team has worked with ASM International Chapter and ASM Chicago Chapter to host a week-long “Materials Camp” for middle/high school teachers who can take numerous materials back to their classroom for hands-on demonstration and vivid illustration of science principles. In addition, this project team has worked with Mahalia Jackson Elementary School (K to 8th graders), Learn Charter School (6-to-8th graders), and De LaSalle High School (9-to-12th graders) in the Science Café program to inspire underrepresented minority students to pursue STEM career.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2025
Modified by: Leon L Shaw
